For the next four weeks, | will
be unable to use our washer
until our addition to the house
is completed.


For the past two Sundays
have been bundling our dirty
clothes in plastic wastebaskets
and one clothes basket and visit
ing the laundromat nearby.


Sundays are the best time to
go to the laundromat. There are
fewer patrons and less deter
gents and washing solutions to
cause me discomfort.


All went we'll during my first
trip. The three tubs washed our
clothes in the usual halfhour per-
iod. the huge dryer did its job,
except for cotton throw rug.


Last Sunday, armed with a
small brown bag containing my
measure of washing powder and
conditioner, l hoped in my car
and drove to the corner laun-
dromat.


1t was bright day. The sky
was clear and the washers we're
open and empty. placed our
weeks soiled clothing in three
front machines. | started each one
and sat down with a magazine.
The machines whirred and filled.
Nothing seemed wrong.


In less than a half hour the
first machine completed its cycle
and took the camp clothes from
it and placed them in the dryer.
left the dryer door open be-
cause knew the other two ma
chimes would be finished in less
than five minutes.


| sat down and resumed my
reading. The machines whirred
and filled, the red lights con-
tinued to shine, the machines
began to spin. | merely waited
for them to stop. Soon-soon-l
Thoughtful these two machines will
stop.


| waited and waited. The ma
chimes whirred and filled again.
The red lights continued to shine
like some Cyclops staring up
ward. The white machines held
our clothes within their grasp
and watched helplessly.


Another ten minutes passed.
The lavender clock on the wall
made no sounds, but the hands
moved quickly as counted the
minutes.


The dryer stood open waiting
for more clothes and ! debated
whether to push the emergency
button or not. | decided to walt
and see how long these machines
would continue their hayward
ways.


Another woman entered the
place, she had several large
bundles of clothes. told her
how long l had been waiting for
the machines to halt. She said
notice on one machine on that
side said, "Out of order, will
not stop spinning"


| jumped up ready to push the
emergency button on the two
machines. They stopped as If by
a pre-arranged signal. | grabbed
my clothes and hurriedly put them
in the dryer.


While watching the clothes
tumble in the dryer l thought of
one of those science fiction NOV
les which depicts machines be-
coming the rulers of the earth.


For one hour | was the captive
of two automatic washers. What
would happen if all of the ma
chimes we use daily would sudden
ly 60 haywire7 shudder at the
thought


Here is one small vote against

IN several ONTLS " our CONWFV ~ttO|"~I
church bodies are finally beginning to make
some positive steps toward recognizing they
haze part to play in the Negroes struggle to
gain equal rights.


is true that many churches and church
organizations haze aided the Negro in the
United States, some since the days Of slavery.
But, too fen church groups haze allowed them
SelUeS to become more iaUOlUed in the Negroes
woYMly existence excebttOY establishing ms
sion type segregated schools and supporting
mission type segregated churches.


Today, there is a move W5thln the governing
groups of certain national clauY oh bodies to
integyate at long last. Initial steps such as
placing Negroes on church councils and bOaTds
haze been made.


! Several churches h0Ue announced that they
sUelc0nae all persons to their services, but
far reaching announce ment by the heads OF
the churches has not been he0Td


TYaditionally, the Negro churches OF ceT-
tain denominations, Including those IN the
North and South, haze divided into segTe-
gated division regardless Of geographical
boundaries.


1.-THE spirit Of equality is to brevade our
lives then, surely the clsuy cheS must accept
greater share Of esb0nSibihty.
